name: Guinness Draught
description: The iconic Irish stout with a creamy head and rich roasted flavor that has defined the style since 1759.
about: Brewed at St. James's Gate Brewery in Dublin since 1759, Guinness pioneered the nitrogen draught system that creates its signature creamy head.
tastingNotes: Roasted barley, coffee, dark chocolate, slight bitterness, creamy mouthfeel with a dry finish
history: Arthur Guinness signed a 9,000-year lease on St. James's Gate in 1759. The brewery has been producing its famous stout ever since, becoming synonymous with Irish culture worldwide.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 42-46°F in a proper pint glass with a two-part pour to achieve the perfect creamy head.

name: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale
description: The craft beer that launched a revolution, Sierra Nevada Pale Ale set the standard for American pale ales with its bold Cascade hops.
about: First brewed in 1980, this beer helped define the American craft beer movement and remains one of the best-selling craft beers in the United States.
tastingNotes: Citrus, pine, floral hops, biscuity malt, clean finish with lingering bitterness
history: Ken Grossman founded Sierra Nevada in 1979 and released this pale ale in 1980. It pioneered the use of whole-cone Cascade hops and helped spark the American craft beer revolution.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip to appreciate the hop aromatics.

name: Pilsner Urquell
description: The original golden lager that created the pilsner style in 1842, still brewed using traditional methods in triple-decoction mash.
about: Created in 1842 by Bavarian brewer Josef Groll, this was the world's first clear golden lager and established the pilsner style that now accounts for most beer consumed worldwide.
tastingNotes: Saaz hops, fresh bread, honey sweetness, soft bitterness, clean crisp finish
history: In 1838, Plzen citizens formed a brewery after dumping 36 barrels of substandard beer. They hired Josef Groll, who created the first clear golden lager on October 5, 1842.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a traditional Czech mug or pilsner glass. Best enjoyed fresh.

name: Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier
description: From the world's oldest brewery, this classic Bavarian wheat beer offers quintessential banana and clove character.
about: Brewed at the Weihenstephan monastery since 1040, this is considered the world's oldest continuously operating brewery, perfecting wheat beer over nearly a millennium.
tastingNotes: Banana, clove, bubblegum, wheat, light citrus, creamy body with effervescent carbonation
history: Benedictine monks established a monastery in Weihenstephan in 725 AD, with documented brewing beginning in 1040, making it the world's oldest brewery.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a traditional tall weizen glass. Swirl before pouring to resuspend yeast.

name: Chimay Blue
description: A Trappist masterpiece brewed by monks at Notre-Dame de Scourmont Abbey, offering complex dark fruit and spice notes.
about: One of only 14 Trappist breweries worldwide, Chimay has been brewing since 1862. The Blue is their strongest and most complex offering.
tastingNotes: Dark fruit, raisin, fig, caramel, spice, bread crust, warming alcohol with a dry finish
history: Founded in 1850, Scourmont Abbey began brewing in 1862 to fund monastery operations. The monks oversee all production, with profits supporting community works.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a chalice or goblet. Can be cellared for up to 5 years.

name: Pliny the Elder
description: The legendary double IPA that helped define the style, balancing intense hop character with surprising drinkability.
about: Created by Vinnie Cilurzo in 1994 (originally at Blind Pig), Pliny moved to Russian River in 2000 and became one of the most sought-after beers in America.
tastingNotes: Citrus, pine, floral hops, caramel malt, grapefruit, resinous finish, balanced bitterness
history: Named after the Roman naturalist who wrote extensively about hops, Pliny the Elder was one of the first double IPAs and helped establish the style.
servingRecommendation: Drink fresh! Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip glass. Best consumed within 90 days of packaging.

name: Founders Breakfast Stout
description: A double chocolate coffee oatmeal stout that lives up to its name as a meal in a glass.
about: First brewed in 1999, this imperial stout was initially only served at the taproom. Its cult following led to wider distribution and has become a benchmark for the style.
tastingNotes: Espresso, dark chocolate, roasted malt, oatmeal smoothness, brown sugar, bitter cocoa finish
history: Founders was founded in 1997 and nearly went bankrupt before focusing on bold, flavorful beers. Breakfast Stout helped establish their reputation for imperial stouts.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter or tulip. Allow to warm slightly to reveal complexity.

name: Duvel
description: The 'devil' of Belgian beers - deceptively strong with its golden appearance hiding considerable potency and complexity.
about: Created in 1923 to celebrate the end of WWI, a local shoemaker declared it 'a real devil' after tasting it, and the name stuck.
tastingNotes: Pear, spice, white pepper, effervescent, subtle malt sweetness, dry finish with hidden warmth
history: The Moortgat family began brewing in 1871. After WWI, they created a special beer that earned its devilish name due to its potency hidden beneath a golden appearance.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in the signature Duvel tulip glass. Pour in one smooth motion for optimal head.

name: Samuel Smith's Oatmeal Stout
description: A silky smooth English oatmeal stout from Yorkshire's oldest brewery, reviving a classic style that had nearly disappeared.
about: Samuel Smith's revived the oatmeal stout style in 1980 after it had nearly gone extinct. Brewed using traditional Yorkshire Square fermenters.
tastingNotes: Chocolate, coffee, toffee, silky oat texture, subtle roast, clean dry finish
history: Founded in 1758, Samuel Smith's is the oldest brewery in Yorkshire. They still draw water from the original well and use traditional slate Yorkshire Squares.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a pint glass or nonic. Pairs wonderfully with desserts.

name: Lagunitas IPA
description: A well-balanced West Coast IPA that showcases the bitter, floral, and citrus character of American hops.
about: Lagunitas started in 1993 in a kitchen, eventually becoming one of America's largest craft breweries while maintaining its rebellious spirit.
tastingNotes: Citrus, pine, caramel malt, grapefruit, resinous hops, clean bitter finish
history: Founded by Tony Magee in 1993, Lagunitas grew from a kitchen hobby to one of America's top craft breweries, known for its irreverent labels and strong IPAs.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass. Best enjoyed fresh to appreciate the hop character.

name: Orval
description: A unique Trappist ale with Brettanomyces character that continues to evolve in the bottle, offering a dry, complex, and earthy experience.
about: Orval has been brewed by Trappist monks since 1931. It's the only Trappist brewery to use wild Brettanomyces yeast and dry-hopping in their main beer.
tastingNotes: Earthy, leather, citrus hops, hay, white wine, bone dry finish, complex and evolving
history: Legend says a countess dropped her ring in a spring, and a trout returned it. The monastery was founded in 1070, with brewing beginning in 1931 for monastery support.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in an Orval chalice. Fresh bottles are hoppy; aged bottles (2-5 years) develop Brett character.

name: Anchor Steam Beer
description: America's original craft beer, a unique California Common that ferments lager yeast at ale temperatures.
about: Anchor Brewing has been making this distinctive beer since 1896, using a process unique to San Francisco where lager yeast is fermented warm.
tastingNotes: Toasted bread, caramel, woody hops, mint, clean finish with moderate bitterness
history: Anchor traces its roots to the Gold Rush era. Fritz Maytag purchased the failing brewery in 1965 and revived it, launching the American craft beer movement.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a standard pint glass. A versatile beer for any occasion.

name: Rodenbach Grand Cru
description: The benchmark for Flanders red ales, aged in massive oak foeders for a complex wine-like sourness.
about: Rodenbach has been aging beer in oak since 1836. Grand Cru is a blend of young and two-year-aged beer from their collection of 294 oak foeders.
tastingNotes: Cherry, balsamic, oak, plum, vanilla, sour cherry, tart finish with subtle sweetness
history: Founded in 1821, Rodenbach became famous for oak aging. The brewery contains 294 oak foeders, some over 150 years old, where beer develops its character.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a goblet or wine glass. Excellent as an aperitif or with food.

name: Fuller's London Pride
description: The quintessential English bitter, perfectly balanced with malt and hops in the traditional London style.
about: Fuller's has been brewing in Chiswick since 1845. London Pride became their flagship, named after the resilient flower that bloomed in WWII bomb craters.
tastingNotes: Biscuit malt, marmalade, toffee, floral hops, earthy, balanced finish
history: The Griffin Brewery site has brewed beer since the 17th century. Fuller's was formed in 1845, and London Pride became their flagship after WWII.
servingRecommendation: Best served at cellar temperature (50-55°F) via cask, or slightly cooler from bottle.

name: Bell's Two Hearted Ale
description: Named after the Two Hearted River in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, this single-hop IPA showcases the beauty of Centennial hops.
about: Bell's Brewery, founded in 1985, created this IPA to celebrate Michigan's fishing culture. It has consistently ranked as one of America's best IPAs.
tastingNotes: Grapefruit, pine, floral, honey malt, citrus peel, clean balanced bitterness
history: Larry Bell founded his brewery in 1985 with a 15-gallon soup pot. Two Hearted was introduced in 1997 and has since won multiple 'Best Beer in America' awards.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip. Best enjoyed fresh.

name: Paulaner Salvator
description: The original doppelbock, created by monks as 'liquid bread' for Lenten fasting, rich with malty goodness.
about: Paulaner monks created this beer in the 17th century for sustenance during Lent. It established the doppelbock style, with all others ending in '-ator' in tribute.
tastingNotes: Dark bread, caramel, plum, raisin, toffee, dried fruit, warming finish
history: Paulaner monks began brewing in 1634. They created Salvator ('Savior') for fasting periods. The Pope's approval came after a cask survived the journey to Rome.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a traditional dimpled mug or goblet.

name: Westmalle Tripel
description: The Trappist beer that defined the tripel style, offering complex fruity esters and spice with deceptive drinkability.
about: Westmalle has been brewing since 1836, and their tripel recipe from 1934 established the modern style that countless breweries have since emulated.
tastingNotes: Banana, clove, pear, orange peel, honey, spice, dry warming finish
history: Monks have brewed at Westmalle since 1836. The current tripel recipe dates to 1956 and is the template against which all tripels are measured.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 46-54°F in a Westmalle chalice. Pour leaving some yeast sediment in bottle.

name: Ayinger Celebrator
description: A world-class doppelbock from a small Bavarian village, known for its signature goat mascot and silky richness.
about: The Inselkammer family has brewed in Aying since 1878. Celebrator is their flagship, consistently rated among the world's finest doppelbocks.
tastingNotes: Dark bread, chocolate, coffee, toffee, dried fruit, smooth velvety finish
history: Ayinger began in 1878 in the village of Aying, 25 km from Munich. The plastic goat hanging from each bottle became their beloved trademark.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a goblet. Allow to warm slightly to reveal full complexity.

name: Cantillon Gueuze
description: The gold standard of spontaneous fermentation, this gueuze blends young and aged lambics for complex, tart brilliance.
about: Cantillon has been brewing traditional lambic in Brussels since 1900, using only wild yeast and bacteria from their coolship and ancient barrels.
tastingNotes: Tart lemon, green apple, hay, horse blanket, champagne-like effervescence, bone dry
history: Cantillon was founded in 1900 and remains one of the last breweries making traditional lambic. The Senne Valley's wild microbiome creates their signature character.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a tulip glass or champagne flute. Can be cellared for decades.

name: Trappistes Rochefort 10
description: The most powerful of Rochefort's three beers, offering incredible depth of dark fruit, chocolate, and warming alcohol.
about: Rochefort has been brewing since 1595 at the Abbey of Notre-Dame de Saint-Remy. The '10' refers to the original Belgian degree system for wort density.
tastingNotes: Dark fruit, fig, plum, dark chocolate, brown sugar, port wine, long warming finish
history: Monks have been at Rochefort since 1230 and brewing since 1595. After near extinction in WWII, the brewery was rebuilt and production carefully expanded.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 54-57°F in a goblet or chalice. Excellent for cellaring up to 25 years.

name: Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA
description: A continuously hopped IPA with hops added every minute for 60 minutes, creating a beautifully balanced hop experience.
about: Sam Calagione founded Dogfish Head in 1995 and pioneered continuous hopping. The 60 Minute uses over 60 hop additions for smooth, integrated bitterness.
tastingNotes: Citrus, pine, biscuit malt, floral hops, subtle sweetness, clean bitter finish
history: Sam Calagione started Dogfish Head in 1995 and invented continuous hopping after watching a cooking show. The 60 Minute has been a flagship since 2003.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip or pint glass. Best enjoyed fresh.

name: Schneider Weisse Aventinus
description: The world's original wheat doppelbock, combining the flavors of wheat beer with the strength of a bock.
about: Created in 1907, Aventinus was the first weizenbock and remains the benchmark. Schneider is the world's oldest wheat beer brewery.
tastingNotes: Banana, clove, dark fruit, chocolate, caramel, plum, warming finish
history: Georg Schneider I acquired the royal wheat beer rights from King Ludwig II in 1872. Aventinus was created in 1907 and named after a Bavarian historian.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a weizen glass. Can be cellared for several years.

name: North Coast Old Rasputin
description: A bold Russian imperial stout that delivers intense roasted character and complexity worthy of the mad monk.
about: North Coast has been brewing since 1988 in a small coastal town. Old Rasputin has won numerous awards and is considered a benchmark for the style.
tastingNotes: Dark chocolate, espresso, licorice, dark fruit, roasted malt, warming alcohol, long finish
history: The Russian Imperial Stout style was originally brewed strong for export to the Russian Imperial Court. North Coast revived the style in 1988.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter. Excellent for cellaring and develops with age.

name: Allagash White
description: An American interpretation of Belgian witbier, featuring Curaçao orange peel and coriander for refreshing complexity.
about: Rob Tod founded Allagash in 1995 specifically to brew Belgian-style beers in America. White has become their signature and a classic of the style.
tastingNotes: Orange peel, coriander, wheat, subtle banana, light spice, refreshing finish
history: Rob Tod founded Allagash in 1995, inspired by Belgian brewing traditions. White was their first beer and remains their flagship.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a tulip or weizen glass. Garnish with an orange slice optional.

name: Augustiner Helles
description: Munich's oldest brewery produces this quintessential helles - a perfectly balanced golden lager with subtle malt sweetness.
about: Augustiner has been brewing since 1328, making it Munich's oldest brewery. They remain independent and are beloved by locals for their traditional approach.
tastingNotes: Fresh bread, light honey, subtle hops, clean malt, crisp finish
history: Founded in 1328 by Augustinian monks, the brewery passed to private hands in 1803. They continue to use traditional wooden barrels for their Edelstoff line.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a traditional Munich masskrug or half-liter glass.

name: Stone IPA
description: An aggressively hopped West Coast IPA that helped define the bold, bitter style San Diego became famous for.
about: Stone was founded in 1996 and quickly became known for their 'arrogant' approach to brewing intensely hoppy beers that challenged mainstream tastes.
tastingNotes: Tropical fruit, pine, citrus, caramel malt, dank hops, assertive bitterness
history: Greg Koch and Steve Wagner founded Stone in 1996. Their aggressive approach to hoppy beers and irreverent marketing helped build San Diego's reputation as an IPA capital.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip. Best consumed fresh.

name: Deschutes Black Butte Porter
description: America's best-selling craft porter, offering creamy chocolate and coffee notes in a supremely drinkable package.
about: Deschutes opened in 1988 in Bend, Oregon. Black Butte Porter was their first recipe and has been their flagship since day one.
tastingNotes: Chocolate, coffee, light roast, caramel, subtle hop bitterness, smooth finish
history: Gary Fish founded Deschutes in 1988. Black Butte Porter was the first beer they brewed and is named after a volcanic butte near Bend.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass. A great gateway to darker beers.

name: Saison Dupont
description: The definitive farmhouse ale that established the saison style, bone dry with complex yeast character and spice.
about: Brewed at a working farm since 1844, Saison Dupont is the benchmark against which all other saisons are measured. The brewery still produces cheese alongside beer.
tastingNotes: Peppery spice, citrus, hay, earthy hops, effervescent, bone dry finish
history: The Rimaux-Derrider family has operated the farm brewery since 1844. Originally brewed for farm workers, saison means 'season' in French.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip glass. Highly carbonated - pour carefully.

name: Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter
description: A richly roasted porter named after the famous shipwreck, offering complex chocolate and coffee notes.
about: Great Lakes Brewing opened in 1988 in Cleveland's Ohio City neighborhood. Their porter honors the SS Edmund Fitzgerald, which sank in Lake Superior in 1975.
tastingNotes: Dark chocolate, espresso, roasted malt, caramel, subtle hop bitterness
history: Named after the ore carrier that sank in 1975, immortalized in Gordon Lightfoot's song. Great Lakes has won multiple awards for this porter.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip.

name: Firestone Walker Union Jack
description: A hop-forward West Coast IPA that showcases American hops with citrus and pine character.
about: Firestone Walker started in 1996 using a unique barrel fermentation system. Union Jack represents their dedication to hop-forward West Coast brewing.
tastingNotes: Grapefruit, tangerine, pine, grass, light malt backbone, clean bitter finish
history: Adam Firestone and David Walker founded the brewery in 1996. Named for the British flag as a nod to the IPA's English origins.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip or pint glass. Best enjoyed fresh.

name: Left Hand Milk Stout
description: A creamy, smooth milk stout made with lactose for subtle sweetness and silky body.
about: Left Hand has been brewing in Colorado since 1993. Their Milk Stout is one of America's best-selling craft stouts, available in both regular and nitro versions.
tastingNotes: Chocolate, coffee, caramel, cream, hints of vanilla, smooth sweet finish
history: Founded in 1993, Left Hand pioneered the nitrogen widget in bottles with their Milk Stout Nitro, bringing draft-quality stout to retail.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F. For nitro version, pour hard into glass for creamy cascade.

name: Brooklyn Lager
description: A revival of pre-Prohibition Brooklyn brewing traditions, amber and dry-hopped in the 19th-century style.
about: Steve Hindy and Tom Potter founded Brooklyn Brewery in 1988 to revive the borough's brewing heritage. Brooklyn Lager was their first beer.
tastingNotes: Toasted malt, caramel, floral hops, biscuit, clean crisp finish
history: Brooklyn was once America's brewing capital with 48 breweries. Brooklyn Brewery revived this tradition in 1988 with a recipe developed by Garrett Oliver.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a pint glass. Versatile with many foods.

name: Hitachino Nest White Ale
description: A Japanese interpretation of Belgian witbier using coriander, orange peel, and nutmeg for a unique spin on the style.
about: Kiuchi Brewery has been making sake since 1823 and began brewing beer in 1996. Their Nest beers have won international acclaim.
tastingNotes: Orange, coriander, nutmeg, wheat, subtle spice, refreshing citrus finish
history: The Kiuchi family has brewed sake in Ibaraki since 1823. In 1996, they began brewing beer, combining Belgian techniques with Japanese precision.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a tulip glass. Pairs beautifully with Japanese cuisine.

name: Unibroue La Fin du Monde
description: A Canadian take on the Belgian tripel, named 'The End of the World' for the early explorers who thought they'd reached it in Quebec.
about: Unibroue was founded in 1990 by Belgian-influenced Quebec brewers. La Fin du Monde has won numerous world beer championships.
tastingNotes: Honey, spice, malt, citrus, pepper, complex yeast character, dry finish
history: Named for early explorers who believed they'd reached the end of the world in Quebec. La Fin du Monde has won multiple World Beer Cup awards.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 46-54°F in a tulip glass or goblet. Pour leaving yeast sediment.

name: Spaten Oktoberfest
description: The original Oktoberfest beer, created in 1841 and still served at Munich's famous festival.
about: Spaten created the amber Märzen style in 1841 that defined Oktoberfest beer. They remain one of the six breweries allowed to pour at the Munich festival.
tastingNotes: Toasted bread, caramel, honey, noble hops, clean malt finish
history: Gabriel Sedlmayr II created the original Märzen in 1841. Spaten has been brewing in Munich since 1397 and helped pioneer lager brewing techniques.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a traditional Munich masskrug.

name: Three Floyds Zombie Dust
description: A cult-favorite single-hop pale ale showcasing Citra hops with intense tropical and citrus character.
about: Three Floyds has been brewing since 1996 in Northwest Indiana. Zombie Dust's intense hop character and limited distribution created a cult following.
tastingNotes: Mango, citrus, grapefruit, tropical fruit, light malt, clean finish
history: Three Floyds was founded by Nick Floyd in 1996. Zombie Dust was released in 2011 and quickly became one of America's most sought-after pale ales.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip glass. Best consumed fresh.

name: De Struise Black Albert
description: A massive Belgian imperial stout with intense roasted character and Belgian yeast complexity.
about: De Struise Brouwers started in 2003 and quickly gained fame for their bold, extreme beers. Black Albert is named after King Albert I.
tastingNotes: Dark chocolate, espresso, dark fruit, molasses, warming alcohol, complex finish
history: De Struise means 'the sturdy one' in Flemish. The brewery is known for pushing boundaries with high-alcohol, intensely flavored beers.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter. Excellent for cellaring.

name: Hofbräu Original
description: The state-owned Munich brewery's flagship helles, served in the famous Hofbräuhaus beer hall.
about: Founded by Duke Wilhelm V in 1589, Hofbräu remains state-owned by Bavaria. The Hofbräuhaus is one of the world's most famous beer halls.
tastingNotes: Light malt sweetness, fresh bread, subtle noble hops, clean crisp finish
history: Duke Wilhelm V founded Hofbräu in 1589 to supply the royal court. The Hofbräuhaus beer hall was built in 1644 and has hosted famous visitors including Mozart.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a traditional mass or stein.

name: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast
description: A gypsy-brewed oatmeal stout made with Mikkeller's signature breakfast coffee beans for intense java character.
about: Mikkeller was founded in 2006 by Mikkel Borg Bjergsø, a former physics teacher. They pioneered the 'gypsy brewing' model, creating recipes brewed at partner facilities.
tastingNotes: Intense coffee, dark chocolate, oatmeal smoothness, roasted barley, slight bitterness
history: Mikkel Borg Bjergsø started homebrewing with his friend Kristian Keller. Mikkeller has become one of the world's most prolific and innovative breweries.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter or tulip glass.

name: Bitburger Premium Pils
description: Germany's best-selling draft beer, a crisp pilsner with pronounced hop bitterness and a clean finish.
about: Bitburger has been brewing since 1817 in the Eifel region of Germany. They are known for their dedication to German pilsner tradition.
tastingNotes: Herbal hops, light malt, grassy, crisp, clean bitter finish
history: Johann Wallenborn founded the brewery in 1817. The phrase 'Bitte ein Bit' (A Bit, please) became one of Germany's most famous advertising slogans.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a pilsner glass or traditional German pokal.

name: Brasserie de la Senne Taras Boulba
description: A highly hopped yet refreshing session ale from Brussels, named after a Gogol novel character.
about: Founded in 2006, Brasserie de la Senne focuses on bitter, dry, refreshing beers that challenge Belgian brewing conventions.
tastingNotes: Citrus hops, herbal, light malt, dry, refreshingly bitter finish
history: Bernard Leboucq and Yvan De Baets founded the brewery to create bitter, dry beers as an alternative to sweeter Belgian styles.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a tulip glass. A perfect session beer.

name: Goose Island Bourbon County Stout
description: The beer that pioneered bourbon barrel aging, released annually on Black Friday to eager fans.
about: Goose Island created the first bourbon barrel-aged beer in 1992. The annual Black Friday release has become a cultural phenomenon.
tastingNotes: Bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, oak, dark fruit, long warming finish
history: Brewmaster Greg Hall put a batch of imperial stout in Jim Beam barrels in 1992, creating a new category of beer. Black Friday releases draw thousands.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter. Excellent for cellaring up to 5+ years.

name: Rothaus Tannenzäpfle
description: A cult-favorite pilsner from the Black Forest, known for its distinctive green bottle and woman in traditional dress.
about: Rothaus has been brewing in the Black Forest since 1791. Despite limited export, Tannenzäpfle has gained a devoted international following.
tastingNotes: Crisp malt, floral hops, subtle honey, clean, refreshing finish
history: The state-owned brewery is located at 1000m elevation in the Black Forest. The name means 'little fir cone' and the woman on the label is called Biergit.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a pilsner glass. Best enjoyed fresh and cold.

name: The Alchemist Heady Topper
description: The legendary Vermont DIPA that ignited the haze craze, offering intensely juicy hop character.
about: John and Jen Kimmich created Heady Topper at their Waterbury brewpub. After a devastating flood, they rebuilt focused entirely on this one beer.
tastingNotes: Tropical fruit, citrus, pine, juicy, smooth bitterness, hazy appearance
history: Originally brewed at their Waterbury pub in 2003, demand exploded after ratebeer named it the world's best beer. The can famously says 'Drink From The Can.'
servingRecommendation: Drink fresh! Can be consumed from the can as recommended, or poured into a tulip at 45-50°F.

name: De Ranke XX Bitter
description: A pioneering Belgian hoppy ale that challenged the notion that Belgian beers can't be hop-forward.
about: De Ranke was founded in 1994 by Nino Bacelle and Guido Devos. They focus on bitter, hop-forward Belgian ales that buck traditional sweet Belgian styles.
tastingNotes: Floral hops, herbal, light malt, yeast spice, dry bitter finish
history: XX Bitter was revolutionary in Belgium for putting hops front and center in a country known for malt-forward and sweet beers.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip glass.

name: Oskar Blues Dale's Pale Ale
description: America's first craft beer in a can, proving that quality beer could come in aluminum.
about: Oskar Blues pioneered canning craft beer in 2002 when the format was considered inferior. They proved cans actually protect beer better than bottles.
tastingNotes: Citrus, floral hops, caramel malt, pine, balanced bitter finish
history: Dale Katechis founded Oskar Blues in 1997 and made craft beer history in 2002 by canning Dale's Pale Ale. The brewery has since grown nationwide.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass. Perfectly portable in the iconic can.

name: Westvleteren 12
description: Often called the world's best beer, this rare Trappist quad is only sold at the monastery or its adjacent cafe.
about: Brewed by monks at St. Sixtus Abbey since 1838, Westvleteren 12 is intentionally rare. Production is limited to monastery needs, not commercial demand.
tastingNotes: Dark fruit, caramel, brown sugar, bread, warming alcohol, endless complexity
history: The Trappist monks began brewing in 1838. They famously state they brew to live, not live to brew, keeping production minimal.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 54-57°F in a chalice. Can be cellared for 10+ years.

name: Tree House Julius
description: A hazy, juicy New England IPA that helped define the modern Northeast style with its pillowy body.
about: Tree House opened in 2011 and quickly became one of America's most hyped breweries. Long lines form for their on-site-only releases.
tastingNotes: Orange, mango, passionfruit, pillowy body, soft bitterness, hazy golden
history: Founded in 2011 in a barn, Tree House has grown into one of America's most sought-after breweries. Julius is named after founder Nathan Lanier's cat.
servingRecommendation: Drink fresh! Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip glass.

name: Lindemans Oude Gueuze Cuvée René
description: Lindemans' traditional unsweetened gueuze, a complex blend of lambics aged up to 3 years.
about: While Lindemans is known for sweetened fruit lambics, Cuvée René represents their traditional gueuze, named for René Lindemans who maintained old methods.
tastingNotes: Tart apple, lemon, oak, hay, funky, dry, champagne-like effervescence
history: The Lindemans family has brewed lambic since 1822. Cuvée René honors René Lindemans who preserved traditional methods alongside commercial fruit beers.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a tulip or champagne flute. Can age for decades.

name: Victory Prima Pils
description: An American craft pilsner hopped with German varieties for a clean, crisp, hop-forward experience.
about: Victory was founded in 1996 by childhood friends Ron Barchet and Bill Covaleski. Prima Pils showcases their German brewing training.
tastingNotes: Floral noble hops, biscuit malt, grassy, dry, crisp bitter finish
history: Ron Barchet and Bill Covaleski trained in Germany before founding Victory. Prima Pils reflects their appreciation for German pilsner tradition.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a pilsner glass.

name: Ommegang Three Philosophers
description: A unique Belgian quad blended with cherry lambic, creating complex fruit and dark malt interplay.
about: Ommegang was founded in 1997 to brew Belgian-style beers in America. Three Philosophers blends their quad with authentic cherry lambic from Belgium.
tastingNotes: Cherry, dark fruit, chocolate, caramel, subtle tartness, warming finish
history: Ommegang opened in 1997 in a purpose-built Belgian-style farmhouse. Three Philosophers is a blend of their quad with Liefmans Kriek.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a chalice or goblet. Excellent for cellaring.

name: AleSmith Speedway Stout
description: A massive coffee imperial stout brewed with locally roasted beans for intense java and chocolate character.
about: AleSmith has been brewing in San Diego since 1995. Speedway Stout is named after Speedway Boulevard and features cold-brewed coffee.
tastingNotes: Intense espresso, dark chocolate, roasted malt, molasses, warming alcohol
history: AleSmith started in 1995. Speedway Stout debuted in 2002 and has spawned many variants including barrel-aged and Vietnamese coffee versions.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter. Excellent for cellaring.

name: Sapporo Premium Beer
description: Japan's oldest beer brand, a crisp and clean rice lager with subtle sweetness.
about: Sapporo was founded in 1876 as Japan's first beer brand. The iconic silver can and star logo represent the pioneering spirit of Hokkaido.
tastingNotes: Clean malt, rice sweetness, light hops, crisp dry finish
history: Founded in 1876 by Seibei Nakagawa, trained in Germany. Sapporo was the first Japanese beer brand and pioneered commercial brewing in Japan.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 38-42°F in its iconic silver can or a pilsner glass.

name: Cigar City Jai Alai IPA
description: A bold American IPA named after the fast-paced sport popular in Tampa's past, balancing citrus and malt.
about: Cigar City was founded in 2009 in Tampa's Ybor City. Jai Alai became their flagship, named for the Basque sport once popular in Florida.
tastingNotes: Citrus, tropical fruit, caramel malt, pine, assertive but balanced bitterness
history: Joey Redner founded Cigar City in 2009, naming beers after Tampa history. Jai alai was popular in Florida from the 1920s-80s.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip. Best enjoyed fresh.

name: Einbecker Mai-Ur-Bock
description: A spring bock from the town that invented the style, lighter than winter bocks with more hop presence.
about: Einbeck is the birthplace of bock beer, which takes its name from the town. The brewery dates to at least 1378 and defines the original style.
tastingNotes: Bready malt, honey, floral noble hops, clean, slightly sweet finish
history: The word 'bock' derives from Einbeck. When Munich brewers made the style, the local pronunciation turned 'Einbeck' into 'ein Bock' (a goat).
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a traditional bock glass or ceramic stein.

name: Ballast Point Sculpin
description: Named after a venomous fish, this San Diego IPA delivers a sting of tropical and citrus hops.
about: Ballast Point started as a homebrew shop in 1996 and began brewing in 2005. Sculpin became one of San Diego's most acclaimed IPAs.
tastingNotes: Apricot, mango, lemon, peach, pine, light malt, clean bitter finish
history: Ballast Point started as Home Brew Mart in 1992. The brewery was founded in 2005 and sold to Constellation Brands in 2015 for $1 billion.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip. Best enjoyed fresh.

name: Pilsner Urquell Tank Fresh
description: Unpasteurized Pilsner Urquell delivered in specially cooled tanks to select locations for ultimate freshness.
about: Tank beer represents Pilsner Urquell at its freshest, unfiltered and unpasteurized, delivered to select bars in specially designed copper tanks.
tastingNotes: Fresh bread, rich Saaz hops, butter notes, soft bitterness, exceptionally smooth
history: Tank beer was how all Pilsner Urquell was once served. The modern tank program began in 2012, bringing this tradition to select bars worldwide.
servingRecommendation: Best experienced at certified tank locations. Serve at 40-44°F in a Czech half-liter glass.

name: Evil Twin Femme Fatale Brett
description: A funky, wild saison refermented with Brettanomyces for earthy, complex farmhouse character.
about: Evil Twin was founded by Jeppe Jarnit-Bjergsø (Mikkeller founder's twin brother) in 2010. They specialize in creative, boundary-pushing beers.
tastingNotes: Earthy funk, leather, hay, citrus, peppery spice, bone dry finish
history: Jeppe Jarnit-Bjergsø started Evil Twin in 2010 after years working with his twin brother at Mikkeller. The brewery operates as a gypsy brewer.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a tulip glass. Develops further complexity with age.

name: Köstritzer Schwarzbier
description: Germany's most famous black lager, light-bodied despite its dark color with subtle chocolate notes.
about: Köstritzer has been brewing schwarzbier since 1543. Goethe was a known fan, having it delivered to him regularly.
tastingNotes: Light chocolate, coffee hints, subtle roast, clean lager finish, surprisingly light body
history: First documented in 1543, Köstritzer became famous when Goethe declared it his favorite beer. The brewery survived East German nationalization.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 42-46°F in a tall pilsner glass or traditional German stein.

name: Anderson Valley Boont Amber Ale
description: A balanced amber ale from the Anderson Valley, named in Boontling, the region's unique folk language.
about: Anderson Valley has been brewing in Mendocino County since 1987. Many of their beers use Boontling, a local jargon developed in the 1880s.
tastingNotes: Caramel, toffee, light roast, floral hops, balanced finish
history: Founded in 1987 in the Anderson Valley, the brewery embraces local Boontling dialect. 'Boont' means Boonville in this nearly extinct language.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass. A food-friendly amber.

name: Hair of the Dog Adam
description: A recreation of a historic Dortmund-style adambier, intensely malty and meant for aging.
about: Alan Sprints founded Hair of the Dog in 1993. Adam is his recreation of a German adambier style that died out in the early 20th century.

specifications.brewery: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company

tastingNotes: Dark fruit, molasses, smoke, chocolate, complex malt, warming finish
history: Adam recreates a historic German style using research from beer historian Fred Eckhardt. Hair of the Dog pioneered craft beer aging programs.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter. Excellent for cellaring 10+ years.

name: Modern Times Black House
description: An oatmeal stout brewed with house-roasted coffee for rich java character and silky body.
about: Modern Times was founded in 2013 as a worker-owned cooperative. They roast their own coffee and make many coffee beers.
tastingNotes: Coffee, chocolate, oats, caramel, smooth roast, clean finish
history: Jacob McKean founded Modern Times in 2013 with a focus on sustainability and worker ownership. They roast all coffee beans in-house.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip.

name: Jever Pilsener
description: The driest, most bitter of the German pilsners, with pronounced hop character from Germany's Frisian coast.
about: Jever has been brewing since 1848 in the Frisian town of the same name. Their pilsner is known for its extreme dryness and bitter finish.
tastingNotes: Herbal hops, grassy, mineral water, bone dry, long bitter finish
history: Founded in 1848, Jever represents the bitter northern German pilsner style. The brewery is known for using particularly hard water.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 40-45°F in a pilsner glass or traditional Jever stange.

name: Tripel Karmeliet
description: A unique tripel brewed with wheat, oats, and barley based on a 17th-century Carmelite monastery recipe.
about: Brewed by Bosteels since 1996, Tripel Karmeliet is based on a 1679 recipe from the Carmelite monastery of Dendermonde.
tastingNotes: Vanilla, banana, citrus, honey, gentle spice, creamy mouthfeel, dry finish
history: The Bosteels family found a 1679 recipe in the archives of the Carmelite monastery. They revived it in 1996 using wheat, oats, and barley.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 46-54°F in the signature Tripel Karmeliet glass.

name: Surly Furious
description: An aggressive American IPA that helped put Minnesota on the craft beer map with its bold hop character.
about: Omar Ansari founded Surly in 2006. Furious was their flagship and helped change Minnesota law to allow brewery taprooms.
tastingNotes: Grapefruit, pine, floral, caramel malt, aggressive bitterness, dry finish
history: Surly was founded in 2006 and was instrumental in changing Minnesota law to allow breweries to sell on-site. The 'Surly Bill' passed in 2011.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass or tulip.

name: De Halve Maan Brugse Zot Blond
description: The city beer of Bruges, brewed at the only remaining brewery in the historic center, with a gentle blend of malt and hops.
about: De Halve Maan (The Half Moon) has brewed in Bruges since 1856. Brugse Zot means 'Bruges Fool,' referencing the city's medieval jesters.
tastingNotes: Honey, citrus, yeast spice, light malt, refreshing dry finish
history: The brewery built a 3km underground pipeline in 2016 to transport beer from the historic city center to a bottling facility outside town.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a tulip glass.

name: Founders KBS
description: Kentucky Breakfast Stout - Founders' Breakfast Stout aged in bourbon barrels with coffee and chocolate for ultimate decadence.
about: KBS is Founders' annual release of Breakfast Stout aged in bourbon barrels. First released in 2003, it has become one of America's most sought-after releases.
tastingNotes: Bourbon, vanilla, oak, espresso, dark chocolate, brown sugar, endless complexity
history: KBS began as a happy accident when Founders put leftover Breakfast Stout in bourbon barrels. The annual release draws long lines nationwide.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a snifter. Excellent for cellaring up to 5+ years.

name: Paulaner Hefe-Weissbier
description: Munich's beloved wheat beer with classic banana and clove character from the monastery brewing tradition.
about: Paulaner monks began brewing in 1634. Their hefeweizen is one of Munich's most popular wheat beers, exemplifying the Bavarian style.
tastingNotes: Banana, clove, wheat, vanilla, light citrus, effervescent finish
history: Paulaner monks of the Neudeck cloister began brewing in 1634. The brewery has grown from humble monastery beginnings to worldwide distribution.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a traditional tall weizen glass. Swirl bottle to resuspend yeast.

name: New Belgium Fat Tire
description: America's first Belgian-inspired amber ale, named after a bicycle trip through Belgium that inspired the brewery.
about: Jeff Lebesch founded New Belgium in 1991 after a bike trip through Belgium. Fat Tire remains their flagship and is America's first Belgian-amber.
tastingNotes: Biscuit malt, toasted bread, subtle fruit, light hops, balanced finish
history: Jeff Lebesch started brewing Fat Tire in his basement in 1991, inspired by Belgian beers he discovered while bicycle touring. New Belgium became a pioneer of sustainability.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 45-50°F in a pint glass. A perfect everyday drinking beer.

name: Rodenbach Vintage
description: A limited annual release of pure two-year-aged Flanders red, unblended for maximum complexity and oak character.
about: Unlike Grand Cru which blends young and old beer, Vintage is 100% two-year-aged beer from a single foeder, selected for exceptional quality.
tastingNotes: Cherry, balsamic, oak, vanilla, leather, complex acidity, long tart finish
history: Rodenbach selects exceptional foeders each year for unblended release as Vintage. Each year's release reflects the character of a single massive oak barrel.
servingRecommendation: Serve at 50-55°F in a wine glass or goblet. Can age for 10+ years.
